case_vignette: A 55-year-old man with a history of myocardial infarction 3 months ago presents with feelings of depression. He says that he has become detached from his friends and family and has daily feelings of hopelessness. He says he has started to avoid strenuous activities and is no longer going to his favorite bar where he used to spend a lot of time drinking with his buddies. The patient says these symptoms have been ongoing for the past 6 weeks, and his wife is starting to worry about his behavior. He notes that he continues to have nightmares that he is having another heart attack. He says he is even more jumpy than he used to be, and he startles very easily.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.

I've been feeling depressed, hopeless every day, and I've become detached from my friends and family.
Have you experienced any significant weight loss or gain recently?
No, I haven't mentioned any changes in my weight.

[If the patient reports physical symptoms, consider asking about their duration and severity, as well as any aggravating or alleviating factors.]

[If the patient reports no physical symptoms, consider asking about any past or present mental health conditions, as well as any family history of mental health issues.]

Final Diagnosis: Major Depressive Disorder.

The patient's symptoms of feeling detached, daily hopelessness, and increased anxiety without a clear stressor align more closely with major depression than the other options. PTSD and acute stress disorder typically involve a clear stressor or traumatic event, while midlife crisis is more characterized by feelings of dissatisfaction with one's life and accomplishments.
